comments:
Simply by unzipping the M7 release over my existing installation and then 
running the eclipse.exe binary, I get the following message:

Unable to read Workbench state, the Workbench will be reset.

I click ok, and then an error dialog box is produced which when clicked 
produces another error box. This will continue as long as I have the patience 
to click the error box, and the eclipse program will not run beyond this 
point. I have to use the task manager to shut the program down and then close 
perhaps five to ten more of the dialog boxes to return to "normal".

The following exceptions are in my log:

Created an attachment (id=21274)
Workspace log file

This is the entire log file
Eclipse must always be installed in a new folder.

That seems to be flawed thinking... in the past eclipse has extracted into a 
directory named eclipse, and upgrades from version to version do not seem to 
break the previous version.

If eclipse must be installed into a new directory, then wouldn't it make sense 
to have the extracted directory named for the version name so that it doesn't 
clobber the previous version.

This is correct for release to release not milestone to milestone because the
plugins do not change version number but their content do change (jars instead
of folders, images deleted, etc).

Please see the following on how to upgrade Eclipse:

http://help.eclipse.org/help30/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.user/tasks/tasks-2.htm

If you still have problems following the procedure above, feel free to reopen.

As for keeping multiple versions of Eclipse, this is how I do it:

d:\eclipse\M6\eclipse    
d:\eclipse\M7\eclipse
